title: Will the James Webb telescope be launched successfully before 1 January 2022?
preds: Sounds like things are going well!
Guess the weather looks a lot better to NASA than it does to me! +20 https://blogs.nasa.gov/webb/2021/12/24/favorable-weather-expected-for-dec-25-launch/
"The latest weather forecast has arrived, and we are still GO for launch of #NASAWebb tomorrow, Dec. 25 at 7:20 am ET (12:20 UTC)!" https://twitter.com/NASAWebb/status/1474424081286062085

"Latest weather forecast just arrived and we are still good to go for tomorrow!" [Arianespace] wrote in a statement posted to Twitter. https://www.space.com/news/live/james-webb-space-telescope-updates I think I'm happy to back this all the way, at this stage.
weather forecast now good, seems unlikely to change in the next day! and opportunities to launch before the end of the year even if tomorrow doesn't work

Rollout complete, and we are still go for tomorrow, Dec 25: https://twitter.com/NASAWebb/status/1474083585216892939
https://twitter.com/ESA_Webb/status/1474290218178170894
https://twitter.com/ariane5/status/1474201765977509892

I feel lucky to be able to ask this question, although it's not known early yet... Thank you for the opportunity. It must be the most flawless project designed in the world. İt will be a miraculous window to the universe...

So far no new delays, the system is on the launch pad now.  Averaging up 8% to the crowd estimate.  Weather forecasts (wunderground) show significant rain and storms for the next 10 days although the hourly forecasts show intermittent windows of several hours duration when a launch could happen.  Anyway, hoping for the best and a successful launch tomorrow - or over the next several days.

If @dowser says it’s 100%, then it’s going to happen! For what it’s worth, I don’t think weather has the potential to cause a long enough delay to push launch outside of the Question timeframe. I also don’t think there’s a significant chance of rocket failure before the main stage separates. All I can say is that my fingers, toes and even eyes are all crossed that JWST will successfully unfold, but unfortunately the odds of everything happening to plan post-Question are definitely less than 100%.

I moved to 50/50, launch is set for 25 December. https://jwst.nasa.gov/content/about/launch.html
Weather will still be a factor but according to today's prediction, there should be a window in the AM for the launch.

Up 2% on rollout start. What's left is: <1% chance of weather delays pushing things out the end-of-year (or short launch issue delay that then rolls over into a weather delay)
<2% but >1% chance of rocket/pad issue causing long delay.
<2% but >1% chance of rocket failure in flight. So, I will not make any more positive moves on probability; the launch itself has to happen before the remaining risk is eliminated. I, of course, might make negative moves, if bad news comes out, in which case I'll have a much worse Brier on this question than @dowser .
Up 20% on passage of time and reported prep progress. I'm certain to win the high Brier score on this question. ;-) Hope it makes L2 and operates successfully!
Rollout of the telescope to the launch pad has begun; target launch date still Dec 25: https://blogs.nasa.gov/webb/2021/12/23/nasa-partners-roll-out-webb-to-launch-pad/

https://apnews.com/article/space-launches-science-business-south-america-a516ed51ec609e6cc07b517ec9cb168d
wind delay, but holding at 96%.  probably wrong, of course.
+15, sounds like they've confirmed an attempt for the 25th. We'll see if the weather cooperates.

After today's update, target still remains Dec 25, with a 32 minutes launch window: https://www.esa.int/Science_Exploration/Space_Science/Webb/Webb_launch_date_confirmed_for_25_December
https://blogs.nasa.gov/webb/2021/12/22/nasa-partners-confirm-webb-launch-on-dec-25/
https://twitter.com/NASAWebb/status/1473762199617388551
https://twitter.com/Arianespace/status/1473760271084703760 According to the planning of operations, the Ariane5 launcher will be rolled-out on December 23, in the morning local time - so this is the next thing to watch for.

Decrementing based on the additional delay.  Weather is not great over the next 10 days and I expect NASA to be cautious (as they should be).  Still think on balance it can be successful if there is an adequate weather window.
Going back up 10 to lean toward yes, there may be more window than it looked like for launches between all the storms.

now delayed to the 25th due to bad weather on the 24th: https://www.nasa.gov/feature/james-webb-space-telescope-launch-update
current forecasts for the 25th are pretty much the same as for the 24th: https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/weather/forecast/dbfmxdss5#?date=2021-12-24 however, in moving to the 25th, they're demonstrating that they're happy to keep working through the christmas period, and there's better weather forecast for the 27th and 28th, so it still seems very plausible that they'll manage to get the launch in before the end of the year.
Down 10% on WX and passage of time. When might the satellite onboard consumables (ed) be necessary to top off or drain and refill?

Yeah I'm going to be bold on this for the last few days of the question. The weather does not look good. @ctsats  https://twitter.com/michaelroston/status/1473415065978257410?t=1UmH46zC5sfuPONwr_HBdg&s=19
Down 5 on the weather delay. Googling French Guinea weather the remainder of the year looks really stormy. Can they find a window in that?

We have another delay of one day, due to adhere weather conditions; the new targeted launch date is Dec. 25. 
Tomorrow evening, local time, another weather forecast will be issued in order to confirm the date of December 25 https://www.nasa.gov/feature/james-webb-space-telescope-launch-update
https://twitter.com/Arianespace/status/1473406135185154053
https://twitter.com/Arianespace/status/1473406138083426305
https://twitter.com/NASAWebb/status/1473412410245632006

Nasa to hold pre-launch briefing later today.   No further problems or delays announced so far.  Moving my bet up.  If the Dec 24th launch is scrubbed due to weather, etc there are only 4 or 5 days left for launch within the competition window. https://spacepolicyonline.com/events/nasa-pre-launch-briefing-for-the-launch-of-jwst-dec-15-2021-virtual-time-tbd/
Closing in on launch day, no news of more delays so far.
"The James Webb Space Telescope is confirmed for the target launch date of Dec. 24, at 7:20 a.m. EST." https://blogs.nasa.gov/webb/2021/12/18/nasas-webb-space-telescope-launch-confirmed-for-dec-24/
All measures for a successful launch have been taken. The weather has been foretasted to be mild for res of year.

Webb is confirmed for the target launch date of 24 Dec, 12:20 GMT / 13:20 CET. 
Encapsulation of the observatory inside Ariane5 is successfully completed. Webb’s launch final readiness review will be held on 21 Dec and, if successful, roll-out on 22 Dec. https://twitter.com/esa_webb/status/1472197587985911809
Okay, comms fixed, 24th is formally confirmed as the new date, there are multiple windows left in the year to handle a bit of bad weather . . .

84% chance of thunderstorms according to https://www.wunderground.com/hourly/gf/cayenne/4.92000008,-52.33000183/date/2021-12-23, 60% chance according to https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/weather/forecast/dbfmxdss5#?date=2021-12-23

I think even with a weather delay, there are enough days after to try again. The wind shear is low on the day of launch and it's scheduled to lift off in the morning, which is before the main diurnal thunderstorm hours. Further, afternoon thunderstorms will favor inland areas more than coastal areas due to sea breeze effect. On the other hand, this is partially an assumption that thunderstorms are not going to be part of another type of larger weather system. Further, the winds are forecast to be around 10mph which could offset everything I just said... unless these winds are taking into account the sea breeze. But the CAPE index isn't that high in some of the models, which is an indicator for strong thunderstorms. Then again it's far out and the accuracy and resolution isn't that high as we want them to be. But I digress. This question asks about the James Webb launch, not the probability of thunderstorms, per se.

Current weather predictions indicate bad weather (including lightening) for the 24th. Already this launch has been delayed several times. 
At Cape Canaveral, around a third of the launches delayed by bad weather are down to the threat of lightning strikes. "We won't launch within 10 miles of a storm, or if it's less than 30 minutes away," says Travis Longmire of the US Air Force 45th Weather Squadron, which is based at Cape Canaveral. https://www.theguardian.com/science/2004/aug/05/thisweekssciencequestions

Giving credit for the com fix.  Forecast for the 24th consists of Thunderstorms, 60 to 80% chance of rain over the day, and ~1 inch total accumulation.  Not ideal weather for a launch but we will see (https://www.wunderground.com/forecast/gf/cayenne/4.92000008,-52.33000183).

"Final encapsulation operations ongoing. 
Need a few more hours to complete them.  Target launch date is December 24 at 12:20 am UTC. 
Confirmation Saturday. " 
- Stéphane Israël, Arianespace CEO, https://bit.ly/3yQwFyh
Up 40%. A bit more detail about the flow path: https://spacenews.com/jwst-launch-rescheduled-for-dec-24/
The moon's gravitational pull and weather are primary factors now, aside from the communication / equipment delay. Update: The communication issue has been fixed, Space dot com reports.

"No earlier than" leaves a week for launch. "The James Webb Space Telescope team is working a communication issue between the observatory and the launch vehicle system. This will delay the launch date to no earlier than Friday, Dec. 24. We will provide more information about the new launch date no later than Friday, Dec. 17."
https://go.nasa.gov/3pYYPmB

Are there bonuses depending on a successful launch in 2021?
Probably yes.

Decrementing based on recent announced delay.  The complexity, visibility, + make me expect that NASA will take as few risks as possible.  Can only imagine the fault tree analysis and scenarios their engineers have gone through and are likely going through now in the background.
Down 45%. Pucker factor is high. If I were the flight director (I'm not) I'd advise a pause (but the whole payload fuel issue has to be VERY complicated).

Apparently, some data cables are dropping frames from the telemetry. NASA: “ We will provide more information about the new launch date no later than Friday, Dec. 17.” For my part, I will update my forecast again no later than Friday, Dec. 17.
Another minor delay. Down 7, the window is tightening.
We have a new delay - new scheduled date no earlier than Friday, Dec. 24: https://blogs.nasa.gov/webb/2021/12/14/webb-space-telescope-launch-date-update/

Updating based on finalization of satellite fueling.  Mating to A5, rocket fueling, and final checks remain.  Weather is still a wild card but I'm hoping this will be successful.  That said I am playing the numbers after updating my probability tree, adding in the fueling completion with Bayesian updating, and finally aggregating with selected peers.
Sounds like it's still on track
10 days before the scheduled launch, all looking good so far: https://twitter.com/ESA_Webb/status/1469970396015476738

perhaps a 2% chance of the rocket failing (Ariane 5s have failed 5 times in a little over 100 launches, but failures concentrated on earlier versions), a 3% chance of bad enough weather to stop the launch (thunderstorms currently predicted for the 22nd at Kourou by accuweather), and a 10% chance of something going wrong enough during the process of attaching the payload that they decide to delay. any delays seem likely to be to after christmas.
Current issues have been overcome and has a launch date scheduled soon. (I am also optimistic that it will launch because I want it to, so that's a bit of bias)
(no change) An interesting take (behind a semi-pay wall): https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2021/12/james-webb-space-telescope-clamp-nasa/620859/

Fueling was completed on Dec 6. > The next steps will start soon for ‘combined operations’. This is when specialists working separately to prepare Webb and Ariane 5 will come together as one team. They will place Webb atop its Ariane 5 launch vehicle and encapsulate it inside Ariane 5’s fairing. https://www.esa.int/ESA_Multimedia/Images/2021/12/Webb_fuelled_for_launch
Hadn't fully appreciated the potential for adverse weather conditions to postpone rocket launches. Updating accordingly.
Up 5% on news (SciAm—no link) that it has been fueled.
Oops. Forgot to update the probability.

Went through past launches and it appears that Ariane Space does launch on Saturdays and Sundays.  Looking at December that would increase the number of potential launch days to about 7 (instead of my 5 or 6 days stated earlier), including the 22nd and excluding Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, and New Years Eve.  This increases the chances a little for success so I'm updating my results to 84%.
20 year project. Not serviceable once it leaves the launchpad. NASA is not in any rush to risk it.

Went through a Fermi exercise to estimate what major milestones have to be reached for a successful launch.  I defined this as follows:
1) All prelaunch activities must be successful (all pre-checks, mating to rocket, fueling, etc)
2) Launch weather must be acceptable (eg, no severe thunderstorms, lightning, etc) within a safety range
3) Based on 1) and 2) a Go vs NoGo must occur, and finally
4) the Vehicle launches successfully.
As I look at most of these, the weather is a concern for two reasons: a) This is the rainy season in French Guiana and the average # rain/storm days in Dec is 18 or 59% (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Guiana).  A look at the long-range forecast confirms daily storms (https://www.wunderground.com/forecast/gf/cayenne/4.92000008,-52.33000183) and b) there are only 5 to 6 "workdays" depending on whether you count the 22nd as one.
While my individual likelihoods for the JWST to complete its checks successfully and launch successfully are high (~95%), my biggest concern is whether there are enough opportunities for acceptable launch weather to justify my previous 90%+ probability of success in the given time window.  Therefore, I am downgrading my probability by averaging the Logits of my prior (92%) with the results of my Fermi Probability Tree (65%) to get a final 82% value.  If anyone sees a major flaw in my reasoning or something that I am missing, please point it out to me.

There has been a long history of delays both this project and other similar projects, and given the extreme amount of resources embedded in JWST, the team is extremely strongly incentivised to delay again if there is any hint of a problem - the risk severity is extremely high. If the launch doesn't take place on the 18th od December, the Christmas holidays make it less likely it would happen before the 1st of January. However, we're very close to the launch date, so the space for more things to go wrong is small.
Good news r.e. the unfolding mishap, back down to only catastrophic failures as potential issues.

(no change and no link, but) ArsTechnica short article mentioned 350 single point failure weaknesses on the JWT. This gives some idea of the magnitude of A-OK pings that might be needed before launch.  (Repeating myself, but there is some general rule of thumb about the likelihood of gotchas that have to be narrowed down that go up exponentially with number of such.)
Adjusting up some based on recent news.

My base rate for this is 96%, just given the overall reliability of the Ariane 5. On top of that, I still think there's a very roughly 5% chance of some combination of events (payload problems, launcher problems, weather) that stack up to 10 more days of delay.

Okay, since the checkout is completed, and they're now scheduled for the 22nd, I'm pushing my odds back up to *almost* where they were before the clamp failure.  (I don't expect another delay to happen, but if there is one, it's more likely to push past January 1st than if the schedule was still for December 18th.)
Up 20% now that @ctsats explained what those (transportation shock thingies) sensors were.
Appears testing concluded ok (https://spacepolicyonline.com/news/jwst-good-to-go/).  Updating using BASH and aggregation with peers
Up 50% on post by @ctsats below. I still would like to know more about installing some of the sensor packages.

Testing concluded OK, the telescope is back on track for launch on Dec 22, fueling operations begin on Nov 25 and will last 10 days: https://twitter.com/NASAWebb/status/1463664164660994048
https://blogs.nasa.gov/webb/2021/11/24/testing-confirms-webb-telescope-on-track-for-targeted-dec-22-launch/
"When you work on a $10bn telescope, conservatism is the order of the day." - https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-59388109

NB: I fully expect the telescope is "fine", for measurable levels of fine. But the launch delay from Dec 18 to Dec 22 is the minimum, and it doesn't take that much more past that in terms of delays before you get someone saying "Well, let's reschedule the launch for after the holidays" and blow January 1.

(Article excerpt:) "...The telescope is considered robust. It has been built to survive the intense shaking and noise when its Ariane rocket climbs away from the launch pad. Part of the development testing for Webb even involved putting it on a table and vibrating it at high frequency.  Engineers have a control room next door to the cleanroom where Webb is being held in Kourou. All the observatory's systems are linked into the monitoring computers inside this room. The functional checks on sub-systems is therefore a reasonably straightforward process. Webb was well advanced in its preparations in Kourou. It was even ahead of schedule...." (https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-59388109) Lowering forecast a bit for now pending results of post-'incident' tests

Down 15%. Interesting about the sensors needing to be installed. At a minimum there will be checks to see if they communicate with the mother ship (and the data streams sort of make sense). (The fueling is a normal activity, but still a high consequence, tricky endeavor.) https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-59388109

Unsure of significance of the "incident" causing the delay.  However, expect there is more downside than upside to the effect on timing.  Reducing using BASH method (eg, similar to Rootclaim's approach) and aggregating with selected peers.
Well, blow me down. I thought @dowser was being way too pessimistic about the chance of something between the local ground checkout and actual launch.
13 days minus this delay of 4 days, 9 days left to bring it up. A week plus a weekend. The delay is about testing, not repairs, yet.

https://apnews.com/article/space-launches-space-exploration-science-business-europe-3952579f91e46b1d392f8ae40f0f18c1
coming down a bit pending developments
Update to reflect possibility of the loading mishap delaying the launch date another week past the planned delay.
Down 50%. "Incidents" have (possible) consequences that are not easily dismissed.

Still no snags reported. I guess that must mean that JWST is quite likely to lift off on schedule indeed. I’m now probably adjusting to an excessively high probability, but I guess I’ll be in good company. Fingers crossed because we all want to see that amazing new data.

Thanks to @jayb for pointing to the passing of the in-Kourou checkout. In accordance with my last projection, moving up a couple points with that completed. Analysis: The successful checkout effectively eliminates the JWST-specific issues left on this question. Everything left is the usual process of launching any payload on an Ariane 5. Ariane 5 has, if I trust the Wikipedia record and am reading it right, two long delays and one failed launch in the last 96 tries. 93/96 = 96.875%.
No obvious indication of problems so far.  Inching up forecast but ready to change if needed.

(no change) I'm too lazy to check the wikipedia entry, but if I remember correctly all along there have been promises and schedules blasted by reality. It is of course possible that the past is not relevant now. OTOH the complexity of the telescope is really pushing boundaries. What would Feinman predict??

Things still appear to be moving along smoothly. Ready to inch further up with similar no-news press releases like today's. Also ready to go the other way at the first hint that something is taking longer than it should.

Current schedule is 18 December.  One can wonder whether a "successful" launch is merely one where the Ariane 5 doesn't blow up, or one that won't be scored that way until all the various bits and bobs are fully unfolded and intact.   I'm prepared to assume the former, since the full process will take quite a while; also, one assumes "launched" would have said "deployed" or something instead.  However, I have often guessed wrong about the GJedi rulings on such quibbles despite having spent decades as a successful and much reviled nitpicker.
If the man with glasses is human; the big picture is... the universe.   The big universe in the small. The small universe within the big.

Updating to reflect reports that things really seem to be progressing well in French Guiana. I will need to see check-outs completed after JWST is fueled and fully integrated with the launcher before forecasting any higher chance of success. In the meantime, just continuing to monitor progress, in the increasingly unlikely event that a major snag is detected.

Late to the party but looks interesting.  The successful launch of the A5 this last week, safe arrival and inspection of the JWST onsite all imply reaching the goal within or before Jan 1.  Going through Bayesian analysis and aggregating, I come up with an average logit = 2.4 which converts to 92%.
Up 10% to be closer to the consensus.

So, with VA 255's success, the chance of "something goes wrong on VA 255 and forces a delay in VA 256" goes away. That leaves:  1) The final checkouts on the JWST itself (unlikely, IMO, to find an issue, since there was a comprehensive checkout before shipping, but the item on which I'm making the biggest guess/assumption). 2) A serious pre-launch rocket anomaly causing a long delay (less than 2%, based on what I gleaned from the Wikipedia write-ups; might be missing data which makes this over-optimistic). 3) In-flight rocket failure (which, since we're past the early teething era of Ariane 5, should be more like the 95/96 record in recent years than the 105/110 record across all Ariane 5 flights). I'm accordingly moving up a couple of percentage points from my initial 93%. I'll pop up a bit further on the report of a successful checkout, or revise sharply lower if there's a report the final checkouts don't pass.

[looks like I jumped the gun with the comments below: I saw video of an Ariane launch at 9:01 eastern on space.com, but I guess that wasn’t the live feed after all... later in the evening VA255 did actually launch, so comments still apply!]  Today’s launch of VA255 is another major milestone for enabling JWST to launch as planned.  I’m expecting to revise my forecast again next week, since there is currently an ongoing systems test that started last Monday that is expected to be completed later in the week. Presumably it’s still too early to definitively conclude that all is good for launch, although things are looking as good as can be at present. “It’s out of its shipping container, it’s gone vertical, and we’ve restarted our final major systems test today,” said Gregory Robinson, Webb’s program director at NASA, in a town hall meeting Monday. “It will last just over a week. “ “There will be no deployments anymore for the observatory until it’s actually in space,” Smith (NASA’s program scientist for Webb) said last week. “So they do all the electrical testing, do some communication checks, go through a final observatory closeout with some final pieces of multi-layer insulation that they put on places (on the spacecraft).” https://spaceflightnow.com/2021/10/19/webb-telescope-unboxed-after-shipment-to-guiana-space-center/

Anticipating no further significant delays in the Arainespace satellite launch now scheduled for today, which should clear the preparation area needed for the planned December launch of James Webb. https://www.space.com/ariane-5-rocket-double-satellite-launch-webcast-october-2021, https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-58888302

Investigation and corrections for VA 255 completed, flight rescheduled for today, reverting my probability for success of VA 256 to what it was (will update again after the results from the "Between 09:01 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. Washington, D.C. time, on October 23" launch window). https://www.arianespace.com/press-release/flight-va255-now-scheduled-on-october-23/

The scheduled-for-today launch (VA 255) has been scrubbed, per https://www.arianespace.com/press-release/flight-va255-postponement-of-the-launch/ This might be minor, it might be a big deal. Since there's no detail yet, I'm revising the odds of James Webb flying (on VA 256)  this year sharply downward, awaiting further data.
Up 15% to be closer to the high consensus. After the October launch I'll tack one way or another.

From my distant outsider's view, things look to be moving along smoothly. The telescope is unpacked and we haven't heard of any specific problems. I think the probability is higher now than it was before that milestone. Moving to the positive side of maybe. I still hesitate to push it too much higher. As I've mentioned before, and as @dowser has pointed out multiple times, scope delivery is so much more important than schedule on this project. Getting a working telescope into space should trump any concern over whether it happens late this year or early next. Once again, I'll keep adjusting upward if things keep appearing to run smoothly as the launch date approaches.
(no change) The LUCY mission is instructive. No one wants to explain any fails related to high profile missions.

Lifting it by 10% as transit is done. I am still uneasy crossing to the other side of maybe given that mission success is all about scope delivery. I will revise up again if all the checks go smoothly and the project team seems publicly confident in the current launch date.

(no change) The 11-24 Oct AWST mentions a possible fairing issue related to this question. They are testing a change on the next launch to see if there will (still) be an issue with trapped air loads possibly impacting the payload when the fairing is released. This sounds like a build it, test it, high consequence issue. I still struggle to fathom the current high consensus. One does not get points for launching something on time, only to have it fail. Comparison class is the Hubble Space Telescope. YMMV

Telescope has reportedly arrived at the launch site. Among other things, Webb's December 18 launch date is apparently dependent upon another Oct. 22 rocket launch not being delayed: https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-58888302
Up 20% to be less far from the consensus. Still amazing how positively expectant the crowd is. Time will tell.
According to the current status of the preparations, the space telescope is expected to take off on December 18, 2021. https://www.br.de/wissen/james-webb-weltraum-teleskop-nasa-100.html

Many risk factors are now excluded. Biggest risks in our opinion were associated to development and cost/budget. The fact that the telescope is underway resolves this piece. Remaining steps are transport, assembling, launch. Historical stats show high chances of success for all steps. Transport was affected by a strike (say 1%). Assembling and launch might be affected by Covid which is at peak in Fr. Guyane, but current timeline give a buffer of ~15 days. Historical stats on Ariane shows no defect in 20 years and all ground equipment is already on site; so delays are more likely to come from weather conditions. Target launch is Dec 18th, which gives another two weeks of buffer, so one month in total. Question is, in case of a problem, how many days can be lost? Lockdown, site closure are unlikely, so it's more about the usual 50-days process taking longer (30days more = 60% more time, seems a lot). All in all, there are not many major risk identified and we provide a subjective probability in the range of 70-90. Fact remains that there are unknowns, and the security/risk mgmt criteria to authorize a launch is very high, and so delays remain possible -> 10-20% easily incompressible.
Successful Ariane 5 launch last month and the telescope is underway to the launch site, cutting ~half the downside.
"...mission managers have 13 days of schedule margin" means high probability of the rocket being ready at December 18th, weather delays are usually only for a day or two.

Telescope reportedly left port last weekend. Increasing forecast for now mainly based upon this info.: "...mission managers have 13 days of schedule margin to have Webb ready for launch Dec. 18." Source: https://spaceflightnow.com/2021/09/30/webb-on-the-way-to-french-guiana/

The success rate of such launches has been increasing over time, and accelerating in the last several years.  And moving the launch date up by one year means that the sponsors have resolved technical issues, which shortens the time needed for preparation.
due to weather issues and other upcoming troubles i guess too many factors to be in time.

Telescope is being prepared to be shipped to the launch facility in Guiana. The only thing stopping the 12/18 launch date would be a delay in the next scheduled Ariane launch in October, a vehicle stacking/pre-launch test issue or weather delay. Given the importance of the mission, NASA and Arianespace will be super-cautious and will scrub if anything at all looks amiss. But it will launch in late 21, early 22.

"The agency set the new target launch date in coordination with Arianespace after Webb recently and successfully completed its rigorous testing regimen – a major turning point for the mission. The new date also follows Arianespace successfully launching an Ariane 5 rocket in late July and scheduling a launch that will precede Webb. The July launch was the first for an Ariane 5 since August 2020." [1] [1] https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-readies-james-webb-space-telescope-for-december-launch
This one is very close to happening. The problems that most likely would arise are in a delay in takeoffs of other missions in Oct. I will be watching that but it looks like they are ready to go.

The JWST has had a lot of delays historically, but those were about actually building the thing; it has now passed its final ground tests and been crated up. There are a lot of JWST-specific risks still in the future, but those are about mechanical deployment after launch. So what's left is, "Can a crate be successfully shipped from California to French Guiana, successfully be loaded on to an Ariane 5, and the Ariane 5 successfully launch?" I don't think there's a lot of risk in the basics of transporting a crate on-schedule. Maybe I'm wrong, but I'm estimating that at 0%. There's one case in Ariane 5 history of a launch being delayed because of difficulty getting the payload on the rocket, because of a barricade built by striking workers. There currently isn't a labor dispute, so I consider that effectively 0% right now. Of the last question, there are essentially three kinds of risk involved: 1) Rocket failure in flight. The Ariane 5 has a 105/110 lifetime launch success rate, with 95/96 since the early teething was over. 2) Weather preventing launch. There are substantial daily launch windows for the JWST mission, so this is effectively 0% 3) Chance of some anomaly with the rocket detected before launch that requires the delay/cancellation of the launch to repair or replace the rocket. If I trust Wikipedia's completeness on this, there are 2 such cases in Ariane 5 history. So, including the early teething failures and subtracting both Wikipedia-documented delays, you get a 103/110 historical performance for Ariane 5 successfully launching by the deadline as a mechanical matter, which looks to me to be the only significant risk of a successful launch not happening.

Read comments from other forecasters. Ticking up. Considering @pstance's confidence as well.

It is true that the launch of the JWST has suffered from numerous delays in the past [1]; however, arguably not all delays have been born equal... Although the previous target date, set way back in the summer of 2020 [2], was for 31 Oct 2021, it was already apparent at least ~6 months before that this date would not be met; here is Space News from May 2021 [3]: > That would suggest JWST will miss its Oct. 31 launch date, although perhaps only by weeks. What about the even older target date for March 2021? Well, this had been pronounced dead already since January 2020, i.e. ~15 months before [4]. The situation looks rather different now, as we are already only ~2.5 months before the target date, and no further delays have been reported yet since Sep 8. It would also seem that the last delay was actually due to Ariane 5 issues, and not of the telescope itself. Given these issues, it seems that the launch of JWST was conditional on at least one successful launch of Ariane 5 before, which would be the very first launch of the rocket in 2021 and after these issues were first detected [3]: ---------------
At a May 11 [2021] media event about JWST, Greg Robinson, program director for the telescope at NASA Headquarters, confirmed there were two Ariane 5 launches ahead of JWST. “They’re going through the process of getting the rocket ready for the upcoming launch, the first of three,” he said. “Once they launch, we’ll be able to launch in about four months after that.” That would suggest JWST will miss its Oct. 31 launch date, although perhaps only by weeks. An Ariane 5 launch of Eutelsat Quantum and Star One D2 at the beginning of the third quarter, or early July, would allow for a launch of JWST in early November, four months later.
---------------- Well, now this launch (Eutelsat Quantum and Star One D2) has happened successfully on 30 July 2021 [5]. And the new JWST date of 18 Dec seems consistent with the target of "four months later" mentioned above. It is true that the target date of 18 Dec is dangerously close to the closing date of the question (1 Jan); however [3]: ----------------
Unlike planetary missions, JWST does not have to launch in a narrow window. “We have launch windows almost virtually every day,” Bill Ochs, JWST project manager at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center, said at the event. “We have multiple, multiple opportunities for launch.”
---------------- Which means that, unless some serious issue is revealed prelaunch, the mission itself can accommodate delays of just a few days. Success (or at least delays not due to the rocket itself) of the next Ariane 5 launch, scheduled for 22 Oct [6], may allow for increased confidence that the target date of 18 Dec will be met. Here is a rough summary of the last target dates and delays: - June 2018: target set for March 2021 (10-month delay) [7], target abandoned already from Jan 2020 [4] (15 months before)
- July 2020: target set for Oct 2021 (7-month delay) [2], target abandoned from May 2021 (6 months before) [3] 
- Sep 2021: target set for Dec 2021 (1.5 month delay) [1, 8] Space News again, from May 2021 [3]: ----------------
At the May 11 media event, though, project officials said final preparations of the spacecraft are going well, and that it should be ready for shipment to French Guiana by late August, a schedule that would support an Oct. 31 launch. The margin in that schedule has been gradually diminishing, as expected. “When we ship, the schedule margin will be pretty close to zero, but still on plan,” Robinson said, noting there are no “liens” on the schedule for the remaining work before shipment. “Right now we’re in a really good place.” “We’re getting pretty close to the goal line,” he added. “We just need to punch it over.”
----------------- And from the official ESA announcement (Sep 2021) [8]: -----------------
Important milestones of the launch programme for Webb have already been passed or are approaching, such as the final mission analysis review for its launch, the shipment of the Ariane 5 launch vehicle elements from continental Europe to French Guiana, and the scheduled shipment of Webb to French Guiana by the end of September 2021.
---------------- Seems they can do it, but *our* window is really narrow... -----------------

[3] https://spacenews.com/ariane-5-issue-could-delay-jwst/

- Arianespace had a successful launch in July and has another launch scheduled for October, so I'll take the base rate of 3/25 years that the Ariane 5 has had to delay launches plus the ~3% failure rate, for a total of 15%.
- Landsat launch on a similar rocket was delayed because of fuel supply chain issues, but (so far) only by one week. There's plenty of lead time to resolve this but still could come up, I'll give it a ~5% chance of both happening and delaying past Jan 1.

Complex telescope, and most delays to this point relate to that. The folded-up spacecraft has to be shipped through the Panama Canal, Caribbean Sea, etc. prior to launch. Also, only about a two week 'margin' from the current planned 12/18/21 launch until the 1/1/2022 question end. https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/22664709/james-webb-space-telescope-launch-date-december-science-hubble, https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-nail-biting-journey-of-nasas-james-webb-space-telescope-is-about-to-begin/ (Excerpt:) "Ariane 5 rockets have accumulated 110 launches since 1996, 105 of which were successful, yielding a 95.5% success rate. Between April 2003 and December 2017, Ariane 5 flew 82 consecutive missions without failure..." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariane_5) ..Starting off a bit below 50% at least until the spacecraft successfully arrives at its launch site, is successfully prepared, etc.

Initial forecast. I need to check where the vehicle is right now. No awards for launching on time; lots of heads will roll if it goes badly for any reason. The official hurricane season does not end until 30 Nov so there are ample opportunities for WX impacts too.

Given the very large numbers of delays that have already occurred so far in the project’s history (launch was initially supposed to occur in 2007!) the fact that there are still a lot of integration checks to be completed and long-distance transport to the launch site has not started yet, I think the chance of further delay is very high. Given that the current planned launch time is so close to Jan 1, even a very minor further delay will most likely push launch out of the window for this question. https://www.space.com/james-webb-space-telescope-launch-december-2021
